column4: Jerod J. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Computer Science. ~ Supporting host | David Rumsey Collection ~ Supporting host	This data set is designed for testing the performance of optical character recognition algorithms on text in scanned historical map images. Thirty maps from the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries were chosen from the David Rumsey Map Collection (http://davidrumsey.com). Most maps are of individual states
column5: though some are regional and one is of the entire U.S.; most feature little handwritten text. The original MrSid files are converted into uncompressed TIFF images for a manual annotation
column6: stored in XML format.  The authors gratefully acknowledge the David Rumsey Map Collection as the source of the map images
column7: which come with the following notice:  Images copyright © 2000 by Cartography Associates. Images may be reproduced or transmitted

column2: J. J. ~ author | Erik | Learned-Miller ~ author | Allen | Hanson ~ author	Computer ~ supporting host	"We present a semi-Markov model for recognizing

column1: scene text that integrates character and word segmentation
with recognition. Using wavelet features
column2: it requires

column1: only approximate location of the text baseline
and font size; no binarization or prior word segmentation
is necessary. Our system is aided by a lexicon
yet it also allows non-lexicon words. To facilitate inference
with a large lexicon
column2: we use an approximate

column1: Viterbi beam search. Our system performs robustly on
low-resolution images of signs containing text in fonts

atypical of documents."	2008				Grinnell College							Optical pattern recognition | Markov processes | Computer simulation | Text processing (Computer science)				Scene text recognition		Digital Grinnell ~ host	Article							English ~ eng	grinnell:10960	http://hdl.handle.net/11084/10960			Copyright to this work is held by the author(s)

column6: Robert ~ creator	Grinnell College. Chemistry Department. ~ supporting host	"The ionic conductivity of LiBOB-doped electrolytes containing two

column1: silyl solvents
column2: bis[2-(2-methoxyethoxy)ethoxy] dimethylsilane
column4: and [2-(2-methoxyethoxy)ethoxy] trimethylsilane
column6: was measured from 10 C to 50 C using AC impedance spectroscopy to assess their potential use in commercial Li-ion cells. The effects of salt concentration
column7: solvent composition
column8: and temperature on the conductivity of the electrolytes are reported. In addition
column9: conductivity data were fit using the Vogel-Tamman-Fulcher (VTF) equation to obtain the parameters s0
column10: T0
column12: which correspond closely to conductivity and viscosity. All the electrolytes produced conductivities above the 1.0 mS cm1 threshold required for commercial application. The 1:1 (vl) solvent composition possesses the highest conductivity
column13: with the optimal 0.8 M salt-loading yielding the highest s25 at 1.99 ± 0.02 mS cm1."	2014	2014		2014-08-28	Elsevier		"Wilfried V. Barth

column1: grinnell:11475	/Volumes/LIBRARY/ALLSTAFF/DG-Metadata-Review-2020-r1/faculty-scholarship/grinnell_11475_MODS.log	97	grinnell:faculty-scholarship	islandora:sp_pdf		https://digital.grinnell.edu/islandora/object/grinnell:11475			Cycles of Conflict: A Computational Modeling Alternative to Collins’s Theory of Conflict Escalation	Computational Modeling Alternative to Collins’s Theory of Conflict Escalation	McClelland
column2: Kent A. ~ creator		In a new theory of conflict escalation
column3: Randall Collins engages critical issues of violent conflict and presents a compellingly plausible theoretical description based on his extensive empirical research. He also sets a new challenge for sociology: explaining the time dynamics of social interaction. However
column4: despite heavy reliance on the quantitative concept of positive feedback loops in his theory
column5: Collins presents no mathematical specification of the dynamic relationships among his variables. This article seeks to fill that gap by offering a computational model that can parsimoniously account for many features of Collins’s theory. My model uses perceptual control theory to create an agent-based computational model of the time dynamics of conflict. With greater conceptual clarity and more wide-ranging generalizability
column6: my alternative model opens the door to further advances in theory development by revealing dynamic aspects of conflict escalation not found in Collins’s model.	2014			2014-06-16	American Sociological Association		McClelland

column1: grinnell:11646	/Volumes/LIBRARY/ALLSTAFF/DG-Metadata-Review-2020-r1/faculty-scholarship/grinnell_11646_MODS.log	98	grinnell:faculty-scholarship	islandora:sp_pdf		https://digital.grinnell.edu/islandora/object/grinnell:11646			Social Context and the Spread of HIV: A game-theoretic investigation on impacts of social stigma and HIV education on epidemic o	Game-theoretic investigation on impacts of social stigma and HIV education on epidemic outcomes	Ferguson
column2: William D. ~ creator | Nguyen
column3: Trang Kieu ~ creator	Grinnell College. Economics Department. ~ supporting host	We provide a theoretical foundation for analyzing how social stigma and adopted behavioral traits affect the transmission of HIV across a population. We combine an evolutionary game-theoretic model—based on a relationship signaling stage game—with the SIR (susceptible-infected-recovered) model of disease transmission. Our evolutionary model specifies how two types of social stigma—that which accompanies an HIV+ condition and that which follows associating with an HIV+ partner—influence behavioral propensities to honestly report one’s condition (or not) and to unconditionally accept relationships (or not). With respect to reporting an HIV+ condition
column4: we find that condition stigma impedes the fitness of honest reporting
column5: whereas association stigma impedes the relative fitness of concealing an HIV+ condition; and both propensities can coexist in a polymorphic equilibrium. By linking our model to the SIR model
column6: we find that condition stigma unambiguously enhances disease transmission by discouraging both honest reporting and a society’s acceptance of AIDS education
column7: whereas association stigma has an ambiguous impact: on one hand it can impede HIV transmission by discouraging concealing behavior and unconditional relationship acceptance
column8: but it also compromises a society’s acceptance of AIDS education. Our relatively simple evolutionary/SIR model offers a foundation for numerous theoretical extensions—such as applications to social network theory—as well as foundation for many testable empirical hypotheses.	2014	25 August 2014		2014-08-25	Grinnell College		“Social Context and the Spread of HIV: A game-theoretic investigation on impacts of social stigma and HIV education on epidemic outcomes
column9: ” William D. Ferguson and Trang Kieu Nguyen

column1: grinnell:11656	/Volumes/LIBRARY/ALLSTAFF/DG-Metadata-Review-2020-r1/faculty-scholarship/grinnell_11656_MODS.log	99	grinnell:faculty-scholarship	islandora:sp_pdf		https://digital.grinnell.edu/islandora/object/grinnell:11656			Curriculum for the Twenty-first Century: Recent Advances in Economic Theory and Undergraduate Economics		Ferguson
column2: William D. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Economics Department. ~ supporting host	Undergraduate economics lags behind cutting-edge economic theory. The author briefly reviews six related advances that profoundly extend and deepen economic analysis: game-theoretic modeling
column3: collective-action problems
column4: information economics and contracting
column5: social preference theory
column6: conceptualizing rationality
column7: and institutional theory. He offers suggestions for incorporating these into the undergraduate classes at various levels. He argues that game-theoretic representation of collective action problems offers a unifying framework
column8: on par with supply and demand
column9: for political economy. Blending in the other developments deepens our micro-level understanding of internal and external contract enforcement
column10: with implications on nonclearing markets
column12: and distribution. At the macro level
column13: these concepts illuminate the role of institutions in economic development and long-term growth. Undergraduate curricula should incorporate these new approaches.	2011	2011-01-06		2011-01-06	University of Nebraska		Ferguson

column3: it finds that employment decline within unionized industries explains 18% of the post-1981 increase in the gap and that declining union ability to raise wages may explain as much as another 25%. Imports

column2: V. M. ~ creator | Anderson
column3: J. T. ~ creator | Geber
column4: M.A. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Biology Department. ~ supporting host	Sister taxa often differ phenotypically
column5: yet we generally do not know whether trait divergence reflects adaptation to spatially-varying selection. In a reciprocal transplant experiment
column6: we ask whether selection favors the native phenotype in two parapatric subspecies of Clarkia xantiana (Onagraceae)
column7: an annual plant endemic to California. We quantified phenotypic selection in each of the exclusive ranges and the contact zone in two years with contrasting climates. We predicted that in the arid
column8: pollinator-scarce eastern region of the distribution
column9: phenotypes of the native subspecies (parviflora) have an advantage: small leaves
column10: slow leaf growth
column12: and diminutive flowers. In the wetter
column13: pollinator-rich
column14: western range of subspecies xantiana
column15: we expected selection for the opposite phenotypes. We predicted that temporal variation in selection would favor xantiana¬-like traits during the first wet El Niño year and parviflora-like traits in the second dry La Niña year. For subspecies xantiana
column16: selection generally favored native phenotypes in the native garden. However
column17: for parviflora
column18: selection sometimes favored non-native trait values. We found little evidence for pollinator-mediated selection
column19: subspecies differences in pollen limitation to reproduction
column20: or temporal variation in selection. Phenotypic differentiation appears to reflect divergent selection in xantiana
column21: but not parviflora.	2015	2015			Grinnell College		Anderson JT

column3: Anita M. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Mathematics & Statistics Department. ~ supporting host	"We present a new technique to study Jacobian variety decompositions using subgroups of the automorphism group of the curve and the corresponding intermediate covers. In particular
column4: this new method allows us to produce many new examples of genera for which there is a curve with completely decomposable Jacobian. These examples greatly extend the list given by Ekedahl and Serre of genera containing such curves
column5: and provide more evidence for a positive answer to two questions they asked. Additionally
column6: we

column2: Danielle N. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Political Science Department. ~ supporting host	This paper examines the potential role of houses of worship as institutions where individuals can acquire civic skills that can be deployed for political participation in the world’s largest Muslim-majority democracy: Indonesia. Drawing on participant observation of almost 300 worship and non-worship gatherings in seven Muslim
column3: Protestant
column4: and Catholic religious communities in Yogyakarta
column5: Indonesia
column6: as well as interviews with members of these communities
column7: this paper investigates two key questions: 1) what opportunities exist for members of Indonesian worship communities to develop and practice the civic skills that are believed to facilitate political participation? and 2) does civic skill opportunity vary across religious denominations? The study introduces an original Civic Skill Opportunity scale
column8: which
column9: when tested
column10: shows that mosques are less likely to develop the civic skills among their worshippers than are churches. These denominational differences can be explained by a house of worship’s embeddedness in a confessional hierarchy
column12: and the relative size of the religious denomination. This study’s findings could have important implications regarding how we think about religion in Southeast Asia
column13: especially Islam
column14: as an impediment or incubator of democracy.	2016			2016-04-01	Grinnell College		Paper prepared for the Midwest Political Science Association Annual Meeting ~ venue | Harris Faculty Fellowship

column2: Mark B. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Physics Department. ~ supporting host	The mathematical parallels between electrostatics and laminar fluid flow are exploited to develop a set of exercises that allow introductory physics students to discover Gauss’s Law. The primary fluid experiment involves investigating the continuity equation in two dimensions by examining the flow between two closely spaced plates. Extrapolation of the resulting two-dimensional velocity field to three dimensions reveals a radial dependence to the velocity field that is analogous to Coulomb’s Law. This analogy allows the student to predict an electric version of the continuity equation that is Gauss’s Law.	2004	2004-09-13		2004-10	American Association of Physics Teachers		"Schneider

column5: T. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Biology Department ~ supporting host	The hypothesis that ecological differences play a role in the evolution of body colour variation within and between sexes in a radiation of endemic Hawaiian damselﬂies is tested.	2016						Variation in traits that are sexually dimorphic is usually attributed to sexual selection
column6: in part because the inﬂuence of ecological differences between sexes can be difﬁcult to identify. Sex-limited dimorphisms
column7: however
column8: provide an opportunity to test ecological selection disentangled from reproductive differences between the sexes. Here
column9: we test the hypothesis that ecological differences play a role in the evolution of body colour variation within and between sexes in a radiation of endemic Hawaiian damselﬂies. We analysed 17 Megalagrion damselﬂies species in a phylogenetic linear regression
column10: including three newly discovered cases of species with female-limited dimorphism. We ﬁnd that rapid colour evolution during the radiation has resulted in no phylogenetic signal for most colour and habitat traits. However
column12: exposure to solar radiation (as measured by canopy cover) signiﬁcantly predicts body colour variation within sexes (female-limited dimorphism)
column13: between sexes (sexual dimorphism)
column14: and among populations and species. Surprisingly
column15: the degree of sexual dimorphism in body colour is also positively correlated with the degree of habitat differences between sexes. Speciﬁcally
column16: redder colouration is associated with more exposure to solar radiation
column17: both within and between species. We discuss potential functions of the pigmentation
column18: including antioxidant properties that would explain the association with light (speciﬁcally UV) exposure
column19: and consider alternative mechanisms that may drive these patterns of sexual dimorphism and colour variation. ~ note | Cooper

column6: and evidence-based decisions marks the U.S. presidency
column7: wherein many processes and decisions are structured by the analysis of data. An approach with historical precedent
column8: reliance on data was prominent under Obama
column9: and is even under Trump
column10: despite signals to the contrary. This article examines three cases from the Obama era: microtargeting in electoral campaigns
column12: and signature drone strikes employed by the national security apparatus. It also reflects on the early Trump administration. The processes described are highly dependent on data
column13: technically big data in two instances. The article examines the cases both on their own terms and in the context of a critical lens that directs attention to the political economy of the data. The analysis helps unpack the allure of data and analytics as well as the challenges in structuring an environment with a measured approach to data and big data
column14: which would examine both their potential and drawback. ~ note | Trish

column44: USA. ~ credits | Hutchinson defined the ecological niche as a hypervolume shaped by the environmental conditions under which a species can ‘exist indefinitely’. Although several authors further discussed the need to adopt a demographic perspective of the ecological niche theory
column45: very few have investigated the environmental requirements of different components of species’ life cycles (i.e. vital rates) in order to examine their internal niche structures. It therefore remains unclear how species’ demography
column46: niches and distributions are interrelated. Using comprehensive demographic data for two well-studied
column49: we show that the arrangement of species’ demographic niches reveals key features of their environmental niches and geographic distributions. In Plantago coronopus
column50: opposing geographic trends in some individual vital rates
column51: through different responses to environmental gradients (demographic compensation)
column52: stabilize population growth across the range. In Clarkia xantiana
column53: a lack of demographic compensation underlies a gradient in population growth
column54: which could translate in a directional geographic range shift. Overall
column55: our results highlight that occurrence and performance niches cannot be assumed to be the same
column56: and that studying their relationship is essential for a better understanding of species’ ecological niches. Finally
column57: we argue for the value of considering the assemblage of species’ demographic niches when studying ecological systems
column58: and predicting the dynamics of species geographical ranges. ~ note | Pironon S

column1: 1. Theory predicts that lack of heritable trait variation and/or maladaptive gene flow can promote the formation of species geographical range boundaries even in the absence of barriers to dispersal. Little is known
column2: however
column3: about the patterns and drivers of differentiation across species’ ranges and whether they influence boundary formation in the field.

column1: 2. Using field measurements
column2: two common garden studies
column3: and QST–FST analyses
column4: we examined environmental and genetic influences on plant phenotype across the geographical range of Clarkia xantiana ssp. xantiana. This annual plant endemic to California has an eastern range border that lacks obvious physical barriers to dispersal.

column1: 3. We find that across opposing environmental gradients that span the species core range
column2: populations are likely to be locally adapted. Populations are phenotypically differentiated from each other in the field as well as common gardens. Traits are correlated with field environmental variables in both settings
column3: and QST –FST comparisons indicate variation in flowering time
column4: degree of branching
column5: and herkogamy may be adaptive. The strength and direction of environment-trait correlations at the range edge are similar to the range centre
column6: and quantitative genetic variation is not reduced. Genetic correlations between traits are generally weak
column7: also suggesting little constraint on trait evolution at the range edge.

column1: 4. Synthesis. For traits measured here
column2: it is unlikely that either low heritable variation at the range edge or maladaptive gene flow strongly inhibits eastward range expansion. Our results suggest that across environmentally complex landscapes
column3: patterns of diversity generated by locally adaptive selection do not necessarily contribute broadly to the formation of range boundaries as predicted. ~ note | Gould BA

column13: Robert D. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Biology Department. ~ supporting host	Understanding the factors that afect rates of adaptation at range margins is crucial for interpreting and predicting changes in species’ ranges.	2014			2014-05-05	Grinnell College		"Evolutionary adaptation is a key driver of species’ range dynamics. Understanding the factors that afect rates of adaptation at range margins is thus crucial for interpreting and predicting changes in species’ ranges. Te spatial structure of environmental conditions is one of the determinants of whether and how quickly adaptations occur. However
column14: while landscape structures at range edges are typically complex
column15: most theoretical work has so far focused on relatively simple environmental geometries.

column1: Using an individual-based allelic model
column2: we explore the efects of diferent landscape structures on the rate of adaptation to novel environments and investigate how these structures interact with the genetic architecture of the trait governing adaptation and the dispersal capacity of the considered species. Generally
column3: we fnd that rapid adaptation is favored by a good match between the coarseness of the trait’s genetic architecture (many loci of small efects versus few loci of large efects) and the coarseness of the landscape (abruptness of transitions in environmental conditions). For example
column4: in rugged landscapes
column5: adaptation is quicker for genetic architectures with few loci of large efects
column6: while for shallow gradients the opposite is true. Moreover
column7: dispersal capacities afect the rate of adaptation by modulating the ‘apparent coarseness’ of the landscape: a gradient perceived as smooth by species with limited dispersal capacities appears rather steep for highly dispersive ones. We also fnd that the distribution of evolving phenotypes strongly depends on the interplay of landscape structure and dispersal capacities
column8: ranging from two distinct phenotypes for most rugged landscapes
column9: over the co-occurrence of an additional third phenotype for highly dispersive species
column10: to the whole range of phenotypes on smooth gradients.

column1: By identifying basic factors that drive the fxation probability of newly arising benefcial mutations
column2: we hope to further broaden the understanding of evolutionary adaptation at range margins and
column3: hence
column4: species’ range dynamics. ~ note | Gould

column2: V. M. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Biology Department. ~ supporting host	Individual plants in gynodioecious populations of Phacelia linearis (Hydrophyllaceae) vary in flower gender
column3: flower size
column4: and flower number. This paper reports the effects of variation in floral display on the visitation behaviour of this species' pollinators (mainly pollen-collecting solitary bees) in several natural and three experimental plant populations
column5: and discusses the results in terms of the consequences for plant fitness.	1991				Grinnell College		Individual plants in gynodioecious populations of Phacelia linearis (Hydrophyllaceae) vary in flower gender
column6: flower size
column7: and flower number. This paper reports the effects of variation in floral display on the visitation behaviour of this species' pollinators (mainly pollen-collecting solitary bees) in several natural and three experimental plant populations
column8: and discusses the results in terms of the consequences for plant fitness. The working hypotheses were: (1) that because female plants do not produce pollen
column9: pollen-collecting insects would visit hermaphrodite plants at a higher rate than female plants and would visit more flowers per hermaphrodite than per female; and (2) that pollinator arrival rate would increase with flower size and flower number
column10: the two main components of visual display. These hypotheses were generally supported
column11: but the effects of floral display on pollinator visitation varied substantially among plant populations. ~ note | Eckhart

I. SOURCES OF TRAIT VARIATION ACROSS A SUBSPECIES BORDER		Eckhart
column2: V. M. ~ creator | Geber
column3: Monica A. ~ creator | McGuire
column4: Christopher M. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Biology Department. ~ supporting host	We report fndings of reciprocal transplant experiments intended to tease apart the roles of differentiation and plasticity in producing phenotypic variation across a geographic border between two plant subspecies. Clarkia xantiana ssp. xantiana and C. xantiana ssp. parvifora are California-endemic annuals that replace each other along a west–east gradient of declining precipitation.	2004				Grinnell College		Abstract. Both genetic differentiation and phenotypic plasticity might be expected to affect the location of geographic range limits. Co-gradient variation (CoGV)
column5: plasticity that is congruent with genetic differentiation
column6: may enhance performance at range margins
column7: whereas its opposite
column8: counter-gradient variation (CnGV) may hinder performance. Here we report fndings of reciprocal transplant experiments intended to tease apart the roles of differentiation and plasticity in producing phenotypic variation across a geographic border between two plant subspecies. Clarkia xantiana ssp. xantiana and C. xantiana ssp. parvifora are California-endemic annuals that replace each other along a west–east gradient of declining precipitation. We analyzed variation in foral traits
column9: phenological traits
column10: and vegetative morphological and developmental traits by sowing seeds of 18 populations (six of ssp. xantiana and 12 of ssp. parvifora)at three sites (one in each subspecies’ exclusive range and one in the subspecies’ contact zone)
column11: in two growing seasons (an exceptionally wet El Nin˜o winter and a much drier La Nin˜a winter). Signifcant genetic differences between subspecies appeared in 11 of 12 traits
column12: and differences were of the same sign as in nature. These fndings are consistent with the hypothesis that selection is responsible for subspecies differences. Geographic variation within subspecies over part of the spatial gradient mirrored between-subspecies differences present at a larger scale. All traits showed signifcant plasticity in response to spatial and temporal environmental variation. Plasticity patterns ranged from spatial and temporal CoGV (e.g.
column13: in node of frst fower)
column14: to spatial CnGV (e.g.
column15: in fowering time)
column16: to patterns that were neither CoGV nor CnGV (the majority of traits). Instances of CoGV may refect adaptive plasticity and may serve to increase performance under year-to-year environmental variation and at sites near the subspecies border. However
column17: the presence of spatial CnGV in some critical traits suggests that subspecies ranges may also be constrained by patterns of plasticity. ~ note | Eckhart

column2: David A. ~ creator | Geber
column3: Monica A. ~ creator | Eckhart
column4: V. M. ~ creator | Tiffin
column5: Peter. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Biology Department. ~ supporting host	We examine the contribution of plant–pollinator interactions to the geographic range limit of the California endemic plant Clarkia xantiana ssp. xantiana. We show that pollinator availability declined from the center to the margin of the geographic range consistently across four years of study.	2012				Grinnell College		Abstract. Mutualisms are well known to influence individual fitness and the population dynamics of partner species
column6: but little is known about whether they influence species distributions and the location of geographic range limits. Here
column7: we examine the contribution of plant–pollinator interactions to the geographic range limit of the California endemic plant Clarkia xantiana ssp. xantiana. We show that pollinator availability declined from the center to the margin of the geographic range consistently across four years of study. This decline in pollinator availability was caused to a greater extent by variation in the abundance of generalist rather than specialist bee pollinators. Climate data suggest that patterns of precipitation in the current and previous year drove variation in bee abundance because of its effects on cues for bee emergence in the current year and the abundance of floral resources in the previous year. Experimental floral manipulations showed that marginal populations had greater outcross pollen limitation of reproduction
column8: in parallel with the decline in pollinator abundance. Although plants are self-compatible
column9: we found no evidence that autonomous selfing contributes to reproduction
column10: and thus no evidence that it alleviates outcross pollen limitation in marginal populations. Furthermore
column11: we found no association between the distance to the range edge and selfing rate
column12: as estimated from sequence and microsatellite variation
column13: indicating that the mating system has not evolved in response to the pollination environment at the range periphery. Overall
column14: our results suggest that dependence on pollinators for reproduction may be an important constraint limiting range expansion in this system. ~ note | Moeller

column2: Robin H. ~ creator		Several real data sets are described and their use in a variety of applied courses at the college level are illustrated. All of the data sets are significantly large to require analysis by computer and provide a rich setting for students to investigate a variety of questions. Some different strategies for organizing student explorations of the data will be discussed.	1991				Grinnell College							Mathematics | Statistics						Digital Grinnell ~ host | Faculty Scholarship ~ host	text	article	11 pages		application/pdf	digitized other analog	RG-O Series 25	English ~ eng	grinnell:26690	http://hdl.handle.net/11084/26690				https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/13fAh_Ndwq2RIG6DxTNrkF_s9UMb-I9gYtUYWahIiVmA/edit?ts=5d23ae00#gid=464539922	99

column2: Robin H. ~ creator		At many colleges a typical mathematics student's introduction to the field of statistics consists of the standard two semester sequence in Probability and Statistics. Indeed
column3: at many smaller colleges
column4: there are the only courses in statistics available for credit towards a math major. A group of statistics educators
column5: with support from the Sloan Foundation's New Liberal Arts Program
column6: has been investigating alternatives to this approach. Our goal is to capture the interest of  mathematically talented students and encourage them to pursue further work in statistics. We believe that this goal can be addressed by developing an applied statistics course which exposes students more quickly to the joys of data analysis
column7: emphasizes the applications of statistics
column8: and utilizes their ability/interest in mathematics. The need for such an alternative course
column9: potential pitfalls in its development
column10: and several specific models for its implementation will be discussed.	1991				Grinnell College							Mathematics | Statistics						Digital Grinnell ~ host | Faculty Scholarship ~ host	text	article	8 pages		application/pdf	digitized other analog	RG-O Series 25	English ~ eng	grinnell:26691	http://hdl.handle.net/11084/26691				https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/13fAh_Ndwq2RIG6DxTNrkF_s9UMb-I9gYtUYWahIiVmA/edit?ts=5d23ae00#gid=464539922	99

column2: Gudmund R. ~ creator		There is an increased emphasis on writing in today's undergraduate curriculum
column3: and papers can play an important role in an introductory statistics course. With the existence of good interactive statistical software it is possible to move the classic introductory statistics course away from the study of formulas to the study of statistical thinking and the role of statistics in society. In such a new course students get an increased understanding of statistical ideas by writing papers across a wide range of topics; actual topics having ranged from a comparison of statistics and religion to a study of the relationship between time of first class in the morning and the distance from the bed to the alarm clock.	1991	August 19

column4: Lee R. ~ creator	Grinnell College. Chemistry Department. ~ supporting host	LaFexCo(1−x)O3 thin films were prepared on fluorine-doped tin oxide conducting glass substrates by spray pyrolysis without any conductive additives and evaluated for their ability to catalyze the oxygen reduction reaction. Onset potential and current density were found to be comparable to platinum
column5: and the  resulting crystallite size was on the order of 20 nm. Coordination of the precursor metal ions by citrate was found not to be advantageous. Results from multiple scan linear sweep voltammetry suggest lattice oxide saturation during reduction of oxygen and lattice oxide depletion upon water oxidation. The color of  the best-performing composition changes dramatically between 1.2 and −1.15 V versus saturated calomel electrode
column6: so X-ray photoelectron spectra of the fully oxidized and reduced films were compared
column7: demonstrating that cobalt in the film changes oxidation state. Performance of the films as a function of iron-to-cobalt ratio is consistent with what others have reported in the literature
column8: indicating that spray pyrolysis is an efficient method to prepare and evaluate new catalytic materials.	2017	2017/11/8			Grinnell College		"LaFexCo(1–x)O3 Thin-Film Oxygen Reduction Catalysts Prepared Using Spray Pyrolysis without Conductive Additives

column7: and activities that create a feeling of community for diverse students and increase students’ awareness of diverse cultures. Research has shown that students who are more engaged are more likely to succeed in college

column3: Becky Jo	Grinnell College. Libraries ~ supporting host	Technical services departments in academic libraries have long struggled to communicate effectively with other library departments

column5: technical services departments are increasingly responsible for providing current information about those resources to public services staff. The authors of this paper describe the process of creating
column6: testing
column7: and implementing LibGuides (proprietary software for building library portals and facilitating information sharing in libraries) as a new way of communicating much-needed information between technical services and public services staff at Miami University Libraries.	2013				Library Resources & Technical Services		Bazeley

column2: Becky Jo	Grinnell College. Libraries. ~ supporting host	For many in the library field
column3: Linked Open Data (LOD) is both a common and an enigmatic phrase. Linked Data has been the topic of many articles
column4: books
column5: conference presentations
column6: and workshops in recent years. The topic
column7: however
column8: is one that many are still working to understand.  This article is a brief primer and survey of the current LOD landscape for those who are either new to LOD or wish to reacquaint themselves with LOD. The article will start with a basic introduction to LOD
column9: including some of the standards and formats involved. The second half will describe some of the major LOD projects and efforts in various fields
column10: including libraries
column12: and museums
column13: and provide links to selected resources for those who want to learn more.	2013				Journal of Library Metadata		"Yoose

column2: Indhira A. | Mark B | Schneider | Schneider
column3: Mark B.		Motivated by a recent experiment involving which-way measurement in atom interference
column4: we developed a completely analogous experiment using visible light. This simple experiment
column5: easily accessible to undergraduate students and the resources of undergraduate departments
column6: facilitates examination of the key elements of which-way measurement
column7: quantum erasure and related mysteries of quantum measurement. The experiment utilizes a Mach-Zehnder interferometer
column8: and visually demonstrates the loss of interference fringes when a which-way measurement is imposed
column9: and the restoration of that pattern when the which-way information is destroyed. This device is also sensitive enough to observe interference fringes arising from single photons. At a level accessible to undergraduates
column10: we present simple analyses of the interference appropriate for the coherent classical field limit
column11: and the single photon limit. We briefly mention related issues of the nature of the photon
column12: pointing to some useful references.	2002			2002-03	American Association of Physics Teachers							Study and teaching | Interference (Light) | Physical measurements | Physics						Liberal Arts Scholarly Repository ~ host | Faculty Scholarship ~ host	text	article

column2: Richard	Grinnell College. Libraries ~ supporting host	"Scholarly communication
column3: in addition to referring to the disciplinary practices that structure the dissemination of scholarly knowledge
column4: has become shorthand for two meanings: on the one hand
column5: it refers to an analytic ""author/reader"" framework that seeks critical understanding of the entire life cycle of scholarly knowledge and the connected roles of researchers
column6: teachers
column7: students
column8: funders
column9: libraries
column10: publishers
column11: and other kinds of agencies in the creation
column12: dissemination
column13: critique
column14: reuse

column2: Epistemology
column3: and LIS in Luciano Floridi		Richard | Fyffe | Fyffe
column4: Richard	Grinnell College. Libraries ~ supporting host	"This paper is a critical reconstruction of Luciano Floridi’s view of librarianship as “stewardship of a semantic environment
column5: ” a view that is at odds with the dominant tradition in which library and information science (LIS) is understood as social epistemology. Floridi’s work helps to explain the normative dimensions of librarianship in ways that epistemology does not
column6: and his Philosophy of Information frames librarians’ traditional stewardship role in terms appropriate for our growing involvement in the management and preservation of information through its entire life cycle. Floridi’s work also helps illuminate what is coming to be called “knowledge as a commons.” Librarianship is concerned with maintaining and enhancing information environments over time
column7: environments that include the behavior of the people who create and use them. The integrity of these environments makes possible the epistemic projects of faculty
column8: students
column9: and other researchers
column10: but librarianship is not
column12: epistemological. Floridi’s ecological reframing of philosophy of information and information ethics
column13: bridging the dichotomy between information and user
column14: has a variety of implications for information literacy education and other academic library services in higher education.
